item.title: Man of the East
item.description: Man of the East is a 1972 Italian spaghetti western film directed by Enzo Barboni starring Terence Hill.

item.title: My Name Is Shanghai Joe
item.description: The Fighting Fist of Shanghai Joe is a 1973 Spaghetti Western kung fu film directed by Mario Caiano and starring Chen Lee as Shanghai Joe. The film was released in a number of alternate titles in the United States, including To Kill or to Die and The Dragon Strikes Back.

item.title: Have a Good Funeral, My Friend... Sartana Will Pay
item.description: Have a Good Funeral, My Friend... Sartana Will Pay is a 1970 Spaghetti Western film directed by Giuliano Carnimeo, written by Roberto Gianviti and starring Gianni Garko.

item.title: Poker with Pistols
item.description: Poker with Pistols is a 1967 Italian Spaghetti Western film directed by Giuseppe Vari.

item.title: Shango
item.description: Shango is a 1970 Italian Spaghetti Western film written and directed by Edoardo Mulargia and starring Anthony Steffen.

item.title: Sting of the West
item.description: Tedeum is a 1972 Italian spaghetti western film directed by Enzo G. Castellari. The title role was initially offered to Tomas Milian, who eventually refused.

item.title: Django the Bastard
item.description: Django the Bastard, also known as The Strangers Gundown, is a 1969 Italian Spaghetti Western film directed by Sergio Garrone. This Gothic-themed Spaghetti Western took advantage of the success of Sergio Corbucci's film Django, hence its title. A similar spaghetti western is the 1967 film Django Kill.

item.title: Return of Shanghai Joe
item.description: Return of Shanghai Joe is a 1975 Western film directed by Bitto Albertini and starring Klaus Kinski.

item.title: A Minute to Pray, a Second to Die
item.description: A Minute to Pray, a Second to Die is a 1968 Italian spaghetti western. It is the fourth and last western directed by Franco Giraldi. It was originally intended as being directed by Sergio Corbucci and the cast was to include also Raffaella Carrà and Renzo Palmer. The American version of the film was heavily cut and handled, including a different ending, and it lasts 16 minutes less than the original version.

item.title: Vengeance Is My Forgiveness
item.description: Vengeance Is My Forgiveness is a 1968 Italian Spaghetti Western film written and directed by Roberto Mauri.
